text: hi my name is Jill I'm a recipe writer
tester and stylist for the New York
Times Magazine and I do all my cooking
in my tiny of New York City kitchen when
I go to someone's home I cross my
fingers that they have a few things if
I'm cooking at their house and they are
one chef knife it doesn't have to be
expensive
thirty dollars is fine just make sure
you keep it sharp take it to a nice
store every three months or so depending
on how often you use it to a paring
knife great for little tasks like
hauling strawberries or coring apples a
large skillet doesn't have to be
expensive again this is a cast iron
about $30 skillet great for frying a
steak eggs sauces a good glass or
stainless steel mixing bowl you don't
need the whole set
you just have one big good one avoid
plastic mixing bowls stainless steel or
glass are great for keeping them clean a
really sturdy very inexpensive with this
spoon you want a good spoon there's
nothing worse than using a little flaky
like weight flimsy spoon that when you
start stirring polenta it kind of cracks
on you again the same thing not too
expensive a really nice sturdy whisk
none of those little like coyly things
that you get at the supermarket and that
you know Bend this is not gonna Bend
this is great another thing you want is
some sort of peeler I prefer these Swiss
peelers go like this new peel butternut
squash peels the skin right off it even
a carrot you know basic peeling a grater
I prefer the microplane grater for
zesting citrus rind grading a nutmeg
grading hard cheeses like pecorino or
parmesan Oh tongs left hand left hand
right hand pick up hot pans with it ream
a lemon or lime with it
tongs are indispensable the next thing
you need especially if you're you love
to cook meat is a thermometer you don't
need the fans
anyone you can get a fancy one this is
like $100 for thermometer it's an
instant read it's fabulous but a cheap
$10 10 $15 one is great to just make
sure it's calibrated stick in ice cold
water then you reset it or boiling water
whichever you prefer stock pop stock
pots are really important for soups
pastas purees everything it's really
good to have a nice large one heavy if
you're following a lot of recipes
especially baking recipes I highly
recommend that you get a scale it's not
essential but if you are a baker or if
you love to follow recipes you might
want to invest in the scale this
particular scale is called my way and I
think it's really great Rose levy
Berenbaum recommended it and I haven't
looked back since and that's it I think
there are a few things in a little
kitchen that you don't need you want to
see my Twinkie pan a candle a mold these
are from France they're copper you have
to treat them their pain another thing
you don't need I purchased a Twinkie pan
and I'd say I love it we don't eat this
I really had to pick three things the
items I would definitely have or a
chef's knife a stockpot and a skillet
and maybe a Twinkie pan
